answers.answer: What they'll do is tell you to check your blood 3-4 times a day and put you on a diabetic diet.
That's fine I just don't want insulin.
If it was just the 1 hour test, they should retest you for the 3 hours, if you fail that one, then you'll have to be put on a diet.

Sometimes if your numbers are high enough they'll skip the 3hr test. As for the insulin and the diet. Depending on how your sugars are they may be able to co from it just with diet, however that's not always the case and some people do require medication.

Unless it's really bad you may have to be put on insulin. They should help you out with a nutritionist to plan meals and snacks. It's easy stuff like egg wires cheese and salsa with toast for breakfast, a yogurt for snack later. Half a turkey sandwich and a chip of milk with grapes for lunch and a snack of peanut butter toast and a cup of milk. Lol that was what got me through it. Good luck!

Since it was so high they may not make you do the 3 hr but you never know. You should call back and ask. But they will first have you check your sugars 4 times a day on a diet(I'm on it and its pretty easy) if you can keep your sugars in the good range then they won't put you on medicine. And if they do it will most likely be a pill form. Unless you keep your sugars way too high then it might be possible you're a real diabetic.
If you failed your 1 hr, with more than 200, they'll just assume you have gd and give you a diet and tell you to check 3-4 times a day!
Okay I just hope its not insulin first

I'm insulin dependent and it's not that bad. The needles are tiny and it doesn't even hurt. As for the pills I was on metformin for diabetes when I got pregnant and they took me off them because there is no research in humans on the effect of the pill on the baby.
But if it's no managed the baby will produce to much insulin on it's own and that's where the complications arise.
The reason I am worried about insulin is because I don't have insurance. I am on Medicaid and mine only covers pregnancy.
I have the same thing and they cover insulin. Anything pregnancy related.
Okay as long as its not bad does GD go away after pregnancy?
You do have an increased risk of developing regular diabetes in the future.

My doctors have me taking a pill called glyburide once a day before breakfast and checking my sugar 4 times a day. But the pill does not seem to be helping much. I am also a very picky eater so controlling my sugar though diet only was really hard. Plus my doctors want my numbers under 130 and when they are over the doctors make me feel like its my fault and that I'm not trying. I know they are worry about my little boy getting to big and having to do a c-secsion but so far he is perfect and on track 5 weeks left. Just don't stress.

question: I got a call today and was told I failed my test and they wanted it at 140 and mine was at 200 something. Are they going to put me on insulin? The nurse acted like she was in a hurry and I couldn't think of all the questions till just now.I guess I don't get the 4 hour one since mine was high
title: GD
